ark:/13030/qt8s86437q.title: Deerly Beloved
ark:/13030/qt8s86437q.description:
When initially coming up for the concept of the game, it was clear there were some severe limitations on the amount of mechanical complexity we could fit into the game as well as some slight graphical limitations. Navigating through the constraints of theme, minimal mechanical complexity, and a deadline really encouraged a great amount of creativity in the design process. Hereâs a window into the development of the gameplay and aesthetic goals of âDeerly Belovedâ:Â 

Theme: Right off the bat, âDeerâ as the theme word intrigued me as I had already explored both âTrafficâ and âSoulmateâ in my Twine Game. It seemed as though it would be less explored by other students, so it might be an opportunity to be innovative or at least different. Once the theme word was chosen, the rest of the theme and concept came naturally. The player would control a deer. What do deer do in the wild? Survive. So survival would be our theme.Â 

Gameplay: With survival as the theme, two core mechanics came to mind; needs management and danger aversion. Maybe thereâs a better term for it, but by needs management I mean managing thirst, hunger, sickness... etc. Danger aversion is pretty self explanatory. My favorite survival game, Minecraft, employs both of these very well. Hunger and Health serve as the needs that need to be managed, and enemies must be avoided, at least initially. In our game, we decided that Hunger would be a good need to manage and danger in the form of hunters wielding guns would be a good threat to avoid. Because both of these mechanics need to be executed simultaneously, the player has to perform a sort of juggling act, transferring between the states of collecting food and avoiding projectiles. If the player focuses only on one, they risk falling victim to the other responsibility. I think it is a simple yet compelling gameplay loop. We chose to quantify the success of the player through a score. This was to give the player an external motivation to continue surviving. In addition we added a 1 up system in which a player can earn an extra life in the form of a fawn, who is willing to take a bullet for the player. This was an attempt to add a little more emotional potency to the game, but by the time the playerâs score hits triple digits the stage is most likely already littered in baby deer and doe corpses. Maybe now it serves more as a criticism of the exploitation of wildlife.Â By choosing to utilize some conventions of classic survival games, as well as implementing several other features, hopefully we succeeded in creating a compelling and innovative gameplay experience.

Aesthetic: Given the somewhat limited graphical capabilities of Construct 3 and it's good presentation of pixelated art styles, a retro pixel art seemed only natural. It also helped that I was a bit obsessed with making pixelated versions of my favorite TV show characters in early high school, so I had a bit of experience going in. Since I made both the textures and sounds for the game, I wanted them to be stylistically consistent. This meant the hard edges of the textures would have to be translated to audio, aka chiptune. I used a really great in-browser music making software called beepbox.co to compose the music and create several other sound assets for the game. Through the use of pixelated textures and bit reduced audio, I think we succeeded in creating a retro pixel art aesthetic.

Goals: To sum it up more concisely, our goal was to create a lofi and nostalgia evoking aesthetic experience, while creating an intriguing gameplay loop to encourage players to rack up high scores.

Problems & Solutions: Through several playtesting sessions with classmates, we got some valuable feedback and insights into the reception of âDeerly Belovedâ. Luckily there was no evil data to speak of, just very awesome, supportive, and informative (awesuppormative) classmates. One instance of this feedback was the initial placement and lack of movement of the hunter enemies. They would sit stationary in the four corners of the stage, endlessly firing at you. This was a bit difficult for some, especially considering the near invisible bullets. In turn, we changed the hunter placement, added movement and increased visibility of the bullets. Many times however, I did stick with Looneyâs advice that you are your greatest critic.Â 

Fin: In the end, creating âDeerly Belovedâ with Sheng was a great opportunity to learn more about game design, art, and people.
